revision.text:
[[File:InviernoenlaciudadRDFeb84.jpg|thumb|Painting of a woman with a rebozo by [[José Julio Gaona]].]] A '''rebozo''' is a long flat garment used mostly by women in [[Mexico]]. It can be worn in various ways, usually folded or wrapped around the head and/or upper body to shade from the sun, provide warmth and as an accessory to an outfit. It is also used to carry babies and large bundles, especially among indigenous women. The origin of the garment is unclear, but most likely derived in the early colonial period, as traditional versions of the garment show indigenous, European and Asian influences. Traditional rebozos are handwoven from cotton, wool, silk and rayon in various lengths but all have some kind of pattern (usually from the [[ikat]] method of dying) and have [[fringe (trim)|fringe]], which can be [[fingerweaving|finger weaved]] into complicated designs. The garment is considered to be part of Mexican identity and nearly all Mexican women own at least one. It has been prominently worn by women such as [[Frida Kahlo]], actress [[María Félix]] and former Mexican first lady [[Margarita Zavala]] and still popular in rural areas of the country. However, its use has diminished in urban areas.
==Description and use of garment== [[File:Mujer en el mercado.JPG|thumb|left|Woman wearing rebozo in Capula, Michoacán]] [[File:Tealrebozo.jpg|thumb|Hand-colored photography by Luis Marquez(photographer), 1937. Mexico]] A rebozo is a long straight piece of cloth which looks like a cross between a scarf and a shawl. Like [[poncho]]s, [[huipil]]s and [[sarape]]s they are classic Mexican garments made of straight, mostly uncut cloth, but rebozos have their own characteristics.<ref name="egonzalez">{{cite news |title= Trabajan por rescate del rebozo |first= Enrique |last= Gonzalez |newspaper= Mural |location=Guadalajara |date=July 19, 2004 |page=8 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Working to rescue the rebozo }}</ref> It is classically a woman’s garment, traditionally hand woven, distinguished by complicated finger woven fringes called rapacejos.<ref name="adelitas">{{cite news |title= Las ''Adelitas'' en el siglo XXI |url= http://www.informador.com.mx/suplementos/2010/232366/6/las-adelitas-en-el-siglo-xxi.htm |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara |date=September 19, 2010 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The "Adelitas" of the 21st century }}</ref><ref name="wavila">{{cite news |title= El rebozo mexicano |author= Wilfrido Ávila García |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/esto/notas/n718237.htm |newspaper= El Sol de Cuernavaca |location=Cuernavaca |date=June 1, 2008 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Mexican rebozo}}</ref> The wearing of the rebozo is said to make the movement of a woman more graceful.<ref name="jiquilpan">{{cite news |title= Continúa el 3er. Festival del Rebozo en Jiquilpan |author= José de Jesús Ceja |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldezamora/notas/n2639450.htm |newspaper= El Sol de Morelia |location=Morelia |date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=3rd Rebozo festival in Jiquilpan continues}}</ref> The wearing of a rebozo by many women is a sign of Mexican heritage, and for that reason, sales of the garment can double before [[Mexican Independence Day]] on September 16.<ref name="duplican">{{cite news|title=Duplican por fiestas patrias la venta de rebozos |author=Rosalba Guzman Ayala |url=http://archivo.periodico.am/nota.aspx?id=424737 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219105723/http://archivo.periodico.am/nota.aspx?id=424737 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 19, 2013 |newspaper=Periódico AM |location=Oaxaca |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Sales of rebozoes double for Independence Day }}</ref><ref name="materias">{{cite web |url= http://www.elrebozo.gob.mx/materias.html |title= Materias Primas |publisher=Municipality of Santa María del Río |location=Mexico |trans-title=Raw materials |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> Because of the nature of the garment, especially the fringes, they should be hand washed. The dye may or may not be colorfast so mild soap should be used.<ref name="entretejida">{{cite news|title=El rebozo una tradición con historia entretejida |author=Rocío Huerta |url=http://www.correo-gto.com.mx/ocio/7426-el-rebozo-una-tradicion-con-historia-entretejida.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219030535/http://www.correo-gto.com.mx/ocio/7426-el-rebozo-una-tradicion-con-historia-entretejida.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 19, 2013 |newspaper=Periódico Correo |location=Guanajuato |date=November 19, 2011 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The rebozo, a tradition with history }}</ref> [[File:FeriadeRebozo2014 25.JPG|thumb|left|150px|Silk rebozo from Santa María del Río, SLP on a mannequin at the Feria de Rebozo in [[Tenancingo, State of Mexico]]]] While all rebozos are rectangular woven cloth with fringes, there is significant variation within these constraints. There are three classes of rebozos. Traditional ones have a design created with the ikat dying technique and come in various set patterns. Regional rebozos are more colorful and their origins can be identified, especially those from [[Oaxaca]], [[Chiapas]] and [[Guerrero]]. Contemporary rebozos experiment with non-traditional fibres and designs.<ref name="marisol">{{cite news |title= Únete al Festival del Rebozo |author= Julia Marisol Hernandez |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/eloccidental/notas/n1395008.htm |newspaper= El Occidental |location=Guadalajara |date=June 13, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Join the Rebozo Festival}}</ref> Sizes vary with lengths varying anywhere from 1.5 to about 3.5 meters long.<ref name="adelitas"/><ref name="perdiendo">{{cite news |title= El Rebozo: tradición que se está perdiendo |author= Raúl Herrera |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldeparral/notas/n2003312.htm |newspaper= El Sol de Parral |location=Parral, Chihuahua |date=March 15, 2011 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Mexican rebozo}}</ref><ref name="elaboracion">{{cite web |url= http://www.elrebozo.gob.mx/proceso.html |title= Proceso de Elaboración del Rebozo |publisher=Municipality of Santa María del Río |location=Mexico |trans-title=Process of creating the rebozo |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> Most Mexican rebozos are made from cotton, wool, silk or [[rayon]].<ref name="perdiendo"/><ref name="arteshistoria">{{cite web |url=http://www.arts-history.mx/sitios/index.php?id_sitio=7041&id_seccion=2722&id_subseccion=574356 |title=El rebozo |publisher=Artes e Historia magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109143029/http://www.arts-history.mx/sitios/index.php?id_sitio=7041&id_seccion=2722&id_subseccion=574356 |archivedate=January 9, 2013 |df= }}</ref> The type of fibre used is the main factor in determining a price of a piece which can vary from a couple hundred pesos to thousands of pesos, with fine pure silk pieces being the most expensive.<ref name="perdiendo"/><ref name="schultz">{{cite news |title= Community celebrates Day of the Rebozo Festival: Tradition: Shawl can be used for many purposes.|first= Alex K. W. |last= Schultz |newspaper= McClatchy - Tribune Business News |location= Washington |date=August 20, 2007 |page=1 }}</ref> The finest silk rebozos can be passed through a wedding ring.<ref name="perdiendo"/><ref name="rockefeller">{{cite book |last1= Marion Rockefeller |first1= Nelson A |last2= Roberts |first2= Ann R|title= Folk Treasures of Mexico : The Nelson A. Rockefeller Collection |year=2010 |publisher=: Arte Público Press |location= Houston, TX, USA |isbn= 9780810911826 |pages=66–67 }}</ref> [[File:StreetvendorRebozo03.JPG|thumb|150px|Young street vendor carrying baby in a rebozo in the city of Oaxaca]] Rebozo colors and patterns vary widely and traditional designs can usually identify where it was made.<ref name="lamagia">{{cite news |title= Exhiben la magia del rebozo mexicano |url= http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/870244.html |newspaper= El Universal |location=Mexico City |date=September 13, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Exhibit the magic of the Mexican rebozo }}</ref> For example, a tightly woven black and [[indigo]] version is identified with the mountains areas of the state of [[Michoacán]].<ref name="rockefeller"/> Designs are generally classified as “classic” and “indigenous.” Classic rebozos come in various colors with designs based on the pre Hispanic art of plumaría, or creating images with feathers. Some of these have their fringes knotted to form images of animals and stares. However, almost all are created with the ikat technique.<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="rockefeller"/> The most famous classic rebozo style is called “de bolitas” whose name comes from little knots of string tied onto groups of threads used in its production.<ref name="aguzman">{{cite news |title= El rebozo una prenda 100% mexicana |first= Alejandro |last= Guzman |author2= Oralia Gonzalez de Ceron |newspaper= Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=September 2, 2000 |page=11 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The rebozo, a 100% Mexican garment}}</ref> Among indigenous groups designs and colors almost always indicate with group the woman belongs.<ref name="entretejida"/> While most rebozos use more than one color, monochrome versions are called “chalinas.”<ref name="lorenzo">{{cite news |title= Santa Maria Del Rio, San Luis Potosi: La tierra del rebozo |first= Lorenzo |last= Armendariz |newspaper= Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=August 15, 1999 |page=16 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Santa María del Río, San Luis Potosí: The land of the rebozo }}</ref> [[File:FeriadeRebozo2014 16.JPG|thumb|left|Fringe of a rebozo from Michoacán, with roadrunner feathers]]
Rebozos have two main functions, that of a garment and that as a carrying aid. As a garment, it can be an indispensable part of the wardrobe of many mestizo and indigenous women, especially those who live in rural areas.<ref name="rockefeller"/><ref name="mexdes">{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/los-rebozos-de-santa-maria-del-rio-san-luis-potosi.html |author= Paloma Quijano Castelló |title= Los rebozos de Santa María del Río (San Luis Potosí) |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=The rebozos of Santa María del Río (San Luis Potosí) |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> As a [[shawl]], it can provide warmth (especially the thicker and wool ones), worn on the head to block the sun as well as for modesty especially in church,<ref name="adelitas"/><ref name="entretejida"/> For city and upper class women who use them, they can be worn inside the home but are most often used as an accessory to an outfit, especially on certain occasions.<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="mexdes"/> As a carrying aid, it can be tied around the head or shoulders most often to carry small children and large bundles, mostly commonly among indigenous women.<ref name="adelitas"/><ref name="perdiendo"/> The rebozo has even figured into Mexican traditional medicine. It has been used as a [[tourniquet]], as support for a woman in later pregnancy, as an aid to a woman in labor, supporting her allowing for rhythmic movements and positioning with aim of making childbirth easier. It can also be used to alleviate headaches by tying it tightly around the head.<ref name="medicina">{{cite news |title= Revalora el rebozo medicina tradicional |first= Rebeca |last= Pérez |newspaper= Mural |location=Guadalajara |date=November 20, 2009 |page=8 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Revaluing the rebozo in traditional medicine }}</ref> Other uses for the rebozo have been in indigenous traditional dances and even as a shroud.<ref name="rockefeller"/><ref name="mexdes"/> One modern and innovative way to wear it has been to twist it around the upper body and fastened to make a kind of blouse or top.<ref name="schultz"/> {{clear}}
==History== [[File:Redandwhiterebozo.jpg|thumb|upright|Hand-colored photography by Luis Marquez(photographer), 1937. Mexico]] The name comes from Spanish, from the verb that means to cover or envelope oneself.<ref name="casaartesano">{{cite web |url= http://www.elrebozo.gob.mx/historia.html |title= Historia Casa de Artesano Santa María de Río |publisher=Municipality of Santa María del Río |location=Mexico |trans-title=History Casa de Artesano Santa María del Río |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> However, there have been indigenous names for it as well, such as “ciua nequealtlapacholoni” in colonial era [[Nahuatl]], which means “that which touches a woman or something like her,” “mini-mahua” among the [[Otomi people|Otomis]] and in the Nahuatl of [[Hueyapan]], [[Morelos]], it is called “cenzotl” comes from a phrase that means “cloth of a thousand colors.”<ref name="casaartesano"/>
The origin of the rebozo is not known, but probably had its beginnings in the very early colonial period.<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="lorenzo"/> The first mention and description of the garment in written records is in 1572 by Friar Diego Duran, according to research done by Ruth D. Lechuga.<ref name="arteshistoria"/> The rebozo itself shows various influences, which probably come from the various cultures that had contact at that time.<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="rockefeller"/> There are various indigenous garments that share physical characteristics with the rebozo. They include the ayate, a rough cloth of [[maguey]] fibre used to carry cargo, the mamatl, which is a cotton cloth also used to carry objects and which often had a decorative border, and the [[tilmàtli|tilma]] (used for carrying and as a garment), a cloth best known from the one [[Juan Diego]] wore and which bears the image of the [[Virgin of Guadalupe]].<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="piedadense">{{cite news |title= La historia del rebozo piedadense |author= Ernesto López Servín |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldezamora/notas/n2589486.htm |newspaper= El Sol de Morelía |location=Morelia |date=June 22, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=History of the La Piedad rebozo }}</ref> There are chronicles that say that [[La Malinche]] carried a cloth called a “Manta del sol” (sun cloth) which was not just used to protect from the sun but also to denote status as decoration.<ref name="wavila"/> However, pre Hispanic clothing and other cloths did not have woven fringes.<ref name="lamagia"/> The main European influence is most likely the Spanish [[mantilla]], although a southern Spanish garment called a rebociño (introduced to the area by the [[Moors]]) may have also played a part. Later influences probably came from Asia with the start of trade from the [[Manila Galleon]].<ref name="wavila"/><ref name="arteshistoria"/>
[[File:Ana-Castillo.png|thumb|left|upright|Writer Ana Castillo in a rebozo]] Its origin was most likely among the lower, mestizo classes in the early colonial period, being most prominent among them first.<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="lorenzo"/> The most traditional rebozos show coloring and designs from the colonial period and mestizo women probably wore them to distinguish themselves from indigenous women but could not afford Spanish finery.<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="rockefeller"/> In 1625, [[Thomas Gage]] noted that blacks and mixed race people in Mexico wore wide strips of clothes on their head instead of the Spanish mantilla.<ref name="arteshistoria"/> In the colonial period how it was worn distinguished married women from single. Married women wore it loose covering the top of the head down over the back. Single women would wrap it tighter, allowing more of the back to be seen.<ref name="perdiendo"/> These garment were initially made of cotton but by later in the colonial period, they were also made of wool and silk.<ref name="casaartesano"/> Their use eventually spread into indigenous communities becoming an integral part of many women’s attire and culture. For example, an Otomi woman used to dip a point of her rebozo into water to indicate that she was thinking of her betrothed or husband.<ref name="mexdes"/><ref name="zaragoza">{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/el-rebozo-es-lo-de-hoy-un-accesorio-potosino-elegante-y-unico.html |author= Juan Manuel Zaragoza Rea |title= El rebozo. Un accesorio potosino elegante y único |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=The rebozo, a elegant and unique accessory from San Luis Potosí |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> One important use for the garment in colonial times to the 19th century was for women to cover their heads in church.<ref name="marisol"/> After its initial development in Mexico, its use spread south into [[Central America]] and even as far as [[Ecuador]].<ref name="aguzman"/>
The rebozo was in common use among the middle and lower classes by the 18th century, with the kind of fibre used to weave it distinguishing the two. The garment was in common use among women by the 18th century. At that time the [[Juan Vicente de Güemes, 2nd Count of Revillagigedo|Count of Revillagigedo]] noted that it was worn by all women except nuns and those of the uppermost classes.<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="arteshistoria"/> The two most common fibres were cotton and the more expensive cotton/silk or silk. Sizes and designs varied but those made with the ikat dying technique became dominant.<ref name="arteshistoria"/> In some parts of Mexico, a woman was given a rebozo by a man as a way to propose matrimony instead of a ring.<ref name="perdiendo"/> The finest rebozos included ornate embroidery including silver and gold thread. One fashion of that century was to embroider country scenes.<ref name="arteshistoria"/><ref name="rockefeller"/>
In 1886, a synthetic silk called [[rayon]] was created in France. The use of this cheaper thread made decorative rebozos more affordable.<ref name="materias"/> Its use as an identifying marker of Mexican identity began at this time as well with even the [[Empress Carlota]] wearing it on various formal occasions, especially while at her country home in [[Cuernavaca]].<ref name="wavila"/> By the end of the 19th century, the garment had become indispensable and their making an important handcraft.<ref name="arteshistoria"/>
Its symbolic function continued into the [[Mexican Revolution]], and item associated with rebel women called “Adelitas,” who carried both babies and weapons wrapped inside past federal checkpoints.<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="elarte">{{cite news|title=¡El arte de usar rebozo! |author=Roberto Arellano Diaz |url=http://archivo.periodico.am/nota.aspx?id=548339 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219111801/http://archivo.periodico.am/nota.aspx?id=548339 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 19, 2013 |newspaper=Periódico AM |location=Oaxaca |date=June 13, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The art of wearing the rebozo! }}</ref> During this time, the rebozo was also often used as a shroud for the dead. Much of the world’s familiarity with the rebozo comes from later cinematic depictions of Adelitas, but it also accentuated the garment’s use with indigenous women, poverty and low socioeconomic station.<ref name="adelitas"/>
[[File:Michelle Obama in Mexico 2010.jpg|150px|thumbnail|First Lady [[Margarita Zavala]] with First Lady of the United States [[Michelle Obama]], April 2010.]] Today, the rebozo can be found in all parts of Mexico and just about all women in the country own at least one regardless of socioeconomic class.<ref name="zaragoza"/><ref name="ogarcia">{{cite news |title=Resaltan en la Ciénega historia y tradición del rebozo michoacano |author=Olivia García |url=http://www.cambiodemichoacan.com.mx/vernota.php?id=155298 |newspaper=El Cambio de Michoacán |location=Morelia |date=July 31, 2011 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=History and tradition of the rebozo highlighted in La Ciénega |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151124121403/http://www.cambiodemichoacan.com.mx/vernota.php?id=155298 |archivedate=November 24, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref name="mfelix">{{cite news |title= Quiere modernizar el rebozo |first= Marcela |last= Félix |newspaper= Mural |location= Guadalajara |date=December 12, 2008 |page=12 |language=Spanish |trans-title=They want to modernize the rebozo}}</ref> In many villages, women are still born in them, grow up with them, get married with them and are buried in them.<ref name="villicana">{{cite news |title= Wrapped in history: Shawl: 'Day of the Rebozo' festival set for Aug. 18 in Porterville.|first= Sarah Elizabeth |last= Villicana |newspaper= McClatchy - Tribune Business News |location= Washington |date=July 12, 2007 |page=1 }}</ref> It is still commonly worn in church by rural women.<ref name="lorenzo"/> During the 20th century, the rebozo came to be seen as both a sign of modesty/tradition and of revolution including in some communities in the United States. For women of the [[Chicano]] movement, it represented the “complete woman” as both feminine and strong, ready to fight for “the Cause.”<ref name="montejano">{{cite book |last1= Montejano |first1= David |title= Quixote's Soldiers : A Local History of the Chicano Movement, 1966-1981. |year=2010 |publisher= University of Texas Press |location= Austin, TX, USA |isbn= 978-0292722903 |pages=173–174 }}</ref> Personalities which have prominently worn rebozos include [[María Félix]], [[Frida Kahlo]], [[Lila Downs]] and model [[Luly Jáuregui]] as well as former Mexican First Lady [[Margarita Zavala]] who was noted for wearing the garment at state functions.<ref name="adelitas"/><ref name="zavala">{{cite web |url= http://www.quien.com/moda/2012/11/29/los-3-rebozos-mas-chic-de-margarita-zavala |author= Ana Paulina Valencia |title= Los 3 rebozos más chic de Margarita Zavala |publisher=Quien magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=The three most chic rebozos of Margarita Zavala |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> The rebozo has appeared in popular culture and media as well as literature.<ref name="aguzman"/> During [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema|Mexican cinema’s Golden Age]] the garment appeared in many movies including one named “El Rebozo de Soledad” (Soledad’s Rebozo).<ref name="egonzalez"/> A de bolita patterned rebozo is mentioned in one of [[Francisco Gabilondo Soler]]’s famous children’s songs.<ref name="mexdes"/> [[File:Rebozo.jpg|thumb|left|Rebozo, 1875-1890, V&A Museum no. T.21-1931]] However, despite its status as a national symbol, its use has diminished among women, especially those in cities.<ref name="arteshistoria"/> One reason for this is that the garment is associated with indigenous groups and poverty and another is that the fine handwoven rebozos, especially of silk are very expensive because of the skilled labor required.<ref name="perdiendo"/><ref name="zaragoza"/> (tenancingohis) Many of the most expensive rebozos are no longer made in many parts of the country, with the exceptions of [[Santa María del Río, San Luis Potosí|Santa María del Río]] and the [[San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí|city of San Luis Potosí]].<ref name="duplican"/> The number of weavers of all types of rebozos have diminished. For example, there are only fifty in the entire state of [[Jalisco]], almost all concentrated in a few municipalities such as [[Sayula, Jalisco|Sayula]] and [[Tuxpan, Jalisco|Tuxpan]].<ref name="egonzalez"/>
Efforts have been made to preserve and promote the use of the rebozo in various ways. In 1953, the Escuela de Rebozo (Rebozo School) was established to teach the weaving techniques used. In 2002 the school won the Premio Nacional de Artes y Tradiciones Populares. Other institutions dedicated to the craft are Museo de Rebozo in [[La Piedad]], Michoacan, the Tejedoras de la Tercera Edad, run by [[CONACULTA]] in [[Acatlán, Veracruz]] and the Taller de Rebocería in the Casa de la Cultura in [[Tenancingo, State of Mexico]].<ref name="zaragoza"/> Since the 1940s, various techniques have been used to modernize the design of the garment, including the use of [[sequin]]s.<ref name="arteshistoria"/> Some modern Mexican fashion designers like Lydia Lavín and Monserrat Messeguer have designed modern versions of the garment, using new fabrics and international patterns, such as those from the Oriente and Africa.<ref name="fusion">{{cite news |title= El rebozo y la fusión de culturas |author= Delgado Olvera |url= http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulos/73642.html |newspaper= El Sol de Parral |location=Mexico City |date=September 21, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The rebozo and cultural fusioin}}</ref>
Rebozos have been the center of museum, cultural and fashion events in Mexico.<ref name="ogarcia"/> Various fairs and festivals dedicated to the garment are held in places such as [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros]],<ref name="matamoros">{{cite web |url=http://www.matamoros.gob.mx/boletines/traen-a-matamoros-el-festival-del-rebozo.html |title=Traen a Matamoros el Festival del Rebozo |publisher=Government of Matamoros |location=Tamaulipas |date=February 20, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Festival of the Rebozo brought to Matamoros |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130221063355/http://www.matamoros.gob.mx/boletines/traen-a-matamoros-el-festival-del-rebozo.html |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Jiquilpan,<ref name="jiquilpan"/> Tenancingo,<ref name="expoferia">{{cite news |title= Expo Feria del Rebozo en Tenancingo |author=Angel Bernal Davila |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldetoluca/notas/n1783584.htm |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130221103133/http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldetoluca/notas/n1783584.htm |dead-url= yes |archive-date= February 21, 2013 |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara |date=September 15, 2010 |accessdate= |language=Spanish |trans-title=Exhibition/Fair of the Rebozo in Tenancingo }}</ref> and [[Zapopan]].<ref name="zapopan">{{cite news |title= Colorido desfile de rebozos a beneficio del adulto mayor en Zapopan |url= http://www.elperiodicodemexico.com/nota_impresion.php?sec=&id=10352 |newspaper= El Periodico de Mexico |location=Mexico City |date=June 10, 2006 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Colorful parade of rebozos to benefit seniors in Zapopan}}</ref> The first Concurso Nacional del Rebozo (National Rebozo Contest) was held in San Luis Potosí in 2004.<ref name="egonzalez"/> The [[Universidad del Valle de Atemajac]], Campus La Piedad created a video called “El Arte del Rebozo” to promote the garment both online and at international events.<ref name="extranjero">{{cite news |title=Se busca promover el rebozo piedadense en el extranjero |author=Eduardo Ruiz |url=http://www.vozdemichoacan.com.mx/rebozos-de-elegancia/ |newspaper=La Vox de Michoacán |location=Morelia |date=July 23, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Looking to promote the La Piedad rebozo abroad }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The university held a conference with the same name in 2012.<ref name="elarte"/> For the 100th anniversary celebrations of the Mexican Revolution in [[Coyoacán]], Mexico City, the rebozo was featured prominently.<ref name="delvalle">{{cite news |title= Destaca Coyoacán tradición del rebozo |first= Óscar |last= Del Valle |newspaper= Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=November 21, 2010 |page=2 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The tradition of the rebozo stands out in Coyoacán}}</ref> The [[Museo Nacional de Culturas Populares]] in Mexico City held an event called “Tápame con tu rebozo” in 2012, to promote the use and sale of the garment.<ref name="lamagia"/> Exhibitions of rebozos have also been held in the [[U.S. Southwest]] with the first Festival del Rebozo in the country held in [[New Mexico]],<ref name="marisol"/> exhibitions at the [[University of Texas Brownsville]] at the Austrey Museum in Los Angeles<ref name="zapopan"/> and [[Fresno, California|Fresno]] holds an annual Day of the Rebozo Festival.<ref name="villicana"/> There is also a museum dedicated to the garment in [[Guadalajara]] called La Casa del Rebozo. In addition to a collection of rebozos in many sizes, colors and textures, it offers conferences, classes, workshops and fashion shows to promote the garment.<ref name="adelitas"/><ref name="marisol"/>
==Production== [[File:SantaMariadelRio145.webm|thumb|Woman weaving a silk rebozo on a backstrap loom at the Taller Escuela de Rebocería in Santa Maria del Rio, San Luis Potosí]] [[Image:Textiles Taller 2.jpg|thumb|Finishing off a rebozo at a textile workshop at the [[Museo de Arte Popular, Mexico City]].]]
Mexico is the main producer and exporter of rebozos, but some are also produced in [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]].<ref name="aguzman"/><ref name="revind">{{cite news |title=Reivindican el uso del rebozo |author=Rodolfo Valadez Luviano |url=http://www.lajornadaguerrero.com.mx/2010/09/19/index.php?section=sociedad&article=008n1soc |newspaper=La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=September 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Revindicating the use of the rebozo |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911002055/http://www.lajornadaguerrero.com.mx/2010/09/19/index.php?section=sociedad&article=008n1soc |archive-date=2014-09-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Average time to make a traditionally woven rebozo is thirty to sixty days with anywhere fifteen to 200 different steps depending on how complicated the design is and the type of fibre being used.<ref name="rockefeller"/><ref name="zaragoza"/> For example, rebozos made of real silk take longer to weave. Those made of rayon have about 3,000 warp threads on average and those made of real silk have about 3,800.<ref name="lorenzo"/>
The dying process is done before weaving, with the most common technique being the ikat method, sometimes called “amarrado” (lit. stingy)<ref name="mexdes"/> In the most traditional work, thread is dyed with natural colors, with colors such as black, blue, red, purple and green but synthetic dyes are now often used.<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="elaboracion"/><ref name="michgob">{{cite web |url=http://michoacan.gob.mx/index.php/temas/gobierno-y-estado/90-turismo/artesania/apatzingan/532-rebozos |title=Rebozos |publisher=State of Michoacán |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203133021/http://www.michoacan.gob.mx/index.php/temas/gobierno-y-estado/90-turismo/artesania/apatzingan/532-rebozos |archive-date=2013-02-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The patterns of the garment are determined by a sequence of colors dyed into the thread, with color changes made similar to tie-dying. Groups of threads are tied together tightly at intervals so that the dye cannot enter some areas. After dying, the knots are cut off.<ref name="elaboracion"/><ref name="michgob"/> The weaving begins by cutting the warp threads to the length of the final product. The number of threads determines the width.<ref name="elaboracion"/> They are woven on both [[Loom#Back strap loom|backstrap looms]] and European style looms.<ref name="entretejida"/> The groups of warp threads are then placed on the loom in order to work out the design that the body of the cloth will have.<ref name="zaragoza"/> After weaving, the last rows of the weft are finger weaved to secure them, which is complicated and meticulous work, often done by women specialized in this.<ref name="mexdes"/> Isabel Rivera and Julia Sánches of Santa María have won national and international awards for their work, with the ability to weave letters into the fringes of rebozos.<ref name="elaboracion"/><ref name="zaragoza"/> In some areas, after they are finished, rebozos are “smoked” with rosemary branches or are stored with apples or quince in order to make them smell good.<ref name="entretejida"/> [[File:InocencioWorkshop12.JPG|thumb|300px|Labor doble design ikat rebozo on a loom at the Inocencio Borboa workshop in Tenancingo]] [[File:FeriadeRebozo2014 53.JPG|thumb|left|Ikat rebozo being made on a backstrap loom at the Feria de Rebozo in Tenancingo]] There are a number of locations in Mexico which produce traditional rebozos including, [[Zamora, Michoacán|Zamora]], [[Ahuirán]], [[Turícuaro]], [[Angahuan]], [[Santa Cruz, Michoacán|Santa Cruz]], [[Tocuaro]], [[Zitácuaro]], [[Cuanajo, Michoacán|Cuanajo]], [[Arocutín, Michoacán|Arocutín]] and [[Tangancícuaro]] in Michoacán,<ref name="entretejida"/><ref name="ogarcia"/> [[Moroleón]] and [[Uriangato]] in [[Guanajuato]],<ref name="entretejida"/> the Altos de Chiapas region, [[Xochistlahuaca]] in Guerrero, the [[Sierra Norte de Puebla]], [[San Pedro Cajonos]], [[Pinotepa de Don Luis]], [[Yalalag]], and [[Santa María Tlahuitoltepec]] in [[Oaxaca]]<ref name="lamagia"/> as well as the Cooperativa Textil Artesanal in the [[Oaxaca, Oaxaca|city of Oaxaca]]<ref name="duplican"/> and [[Chiautempan]], [[Tlaxcala]],<ref name="zaragoza"/> However, there are several important locations whose work are featured in important collections such as that of the [[Rockefeller family]]. These include Santa María del Río, Tenancingo and La Piedad.<ref name="rockefeller"/> [[File:InocencioWorkshop29.JPG|thumb|left|300px|Rebozo fringe intricately finger woven with small beads]] [[Santa María del Río, San Luis Potosí|Santa María del Río]] is a small rural town in the state of [[San Luis Potosí]], containing country homes for the well-to-do in the [[San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí|city of San Luis Potosí]]. The entrance arch of the town states “Santa María del Río, cuna del rebozo” (Santa María del Río, cradle of the rebozo).<ref name="mexdes"/> Even the local baseball team is named after rebozo weavers, called the “Reboceros.”<ref name="expoferia"/> It is known for its production of finely woven rebozos especially in silk and rayon, with cotton ones made as well.<ref name="elaboracion"/> Weaving was introduced to the area shortly after the conquest and gained fame by the 17th century.<ref name="casaartesano"/> Silk production was introduced originally in Oaxaca by the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]]. Despite prohibitions, [[Junípero Serra]] introduced their cultivation into the region in the 18th century, with silk production and weaving becoming widespread by the late 19th century into the 20th.<ref name="materias"/><ref name="mexdes"/> The variety of silk traditionally used in these rebozos is called “catiteo.”<ref name="materias"/> After the [[Mexican Revolution]], the haciendas producing silk were broken up and many weavers turned to rayon and very few are still made with pure silk.<ref name="mexdes"/> Their production is done by families, but only by the women, with a number winning national awards for their work.<ref name="elaboracion"/> In Santa María the use of various browns is a distinguishing characteristic of the region. Other common colors are black, blue, red, purple and green along occasional white threads which appear as flecks in the final product. There are a number of traditional color combinations and designs with names such as calabrote, Rosita, rosarito, culebrilla calado and more.<ref name="elaboracion"/><ref name="mexdes"/> Santa Maria hosts a Feria del Rebozo in August and is home to the Escuela de Rebozo (Rebozo School) and a cooperative called the Taller Escuela de Rebocería.<ref name="lorenzo"/>
The making of cotton rebozos is important in [[Tenancingo, State of Mexico|Tenancingo]] and an image of the garment appears in the municipality’s seal.<ref name="tenangohis">{{cite web |url= http://www.rebozostenancingo.com.mx/historia.php |title= Historia |publisher=Government of Tenancingo |location=State of Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=History |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> Tenancingo’s rebozos come in a wide variety of prices from 400 to 4,000 [[Mexican peso|pesos]], depending on the quality of the cotton, the complexity of the design and the thread count. The craft was developed in Tenancingo by the 17th century and reached its peak during the 19th century. The creation of the garment remains important both culturally and economically, with the work here recognized at the national and international levels.<ref name="gestion">{{cite journal |last= De La Peña Virchez |first= Rosa Guadalupe |last2= Nava Sánchez |first2= Karla Josefina |date=November 12, 2011 |title= Exposición itinerante del rebozo, como estrategia para la revalorización del patrimonio artesanal en el municipio de Tenancingo, Estado de México |trans-title=Exhibitions of the rebozo as a strategy for the revaluing of the artisanal heritage in the municipality of Tenancingo, State of Mexico |journal= Revista Digital de Gestión Cultural |volume=1 |issue=2 |language=Spanish |issn=2007-3321 |accessdate=January 15, 2013 |url= http://gestioncultural.org.mx/revista/02/De_la_Pena_N2_A1.pdf }}</ref> One of the town’s most important weavers is Evaristo Borboa.<ref name="tenmex">{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/la-ciudad-de-los-rebozos-estado-de-mexico.html |title= Tenancingo, la ciudad de los rebozos (Estado de México) |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazines |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=Tenancingo, the city of Rebozos (State of Mexico) |accessdate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref>
The mountain areas of Michoacán have been noted for an indigo blue variety of rebozo, known as the Michoacán or Tarasco rebozo. In the 1930s and 1940s, the city of [[La Piedad]], Michoacán became a major producer of rebozos of both natural and synthetic fibres.<ref name="piedadense"/> In 1946 the Unión de Reboceros de La Piedad was formed and in 1958, the Sindicato Único de Reboceros de La Piedad.<ref name="michgob"/> {{commons category|Rebozos}}
==See also== *[[Aguayo (cloth)|Aguayo]], a similar piece of cloth used in the Andes *[[Dupatta]], a similar piece of cloth used in South Asia {{-}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * Hand-colored photographs by Luis Márquez (photographer) of people wearing or using rebozos in the 1930s at the [http://digital.lib.uh.edu/ University of Houston Digital Library]. [http://digital.lib.uh.edu/u?/p15195coll13,8 Photo 1][http://digital.lib.uh.edu/u?/p15195coll13,21 Photo 2][http://digital.lib.uh.edu/u?/p15195coll13,2 Photo 3]. [http://digital.lib.uh.edu/u?/p15195coll13,23 Photo 4]

{{unreferenced|date=March 2008}} [[Image:1863 harpers.jpg|270px|thumb|right|Thomas Nast immortalized Santa Claus with an illustration for the January 3, 1863 issue of ''Harper's Weekly.'' The first Santa Claus appeared as a small part of a large illustration titled "A Christmas Furlough" in which Nast set aside his regular news and political coverage to do a Santa Claus drawing. This Santa was a man dressed up handing out gifts to Union soldiers.]]
There exists a wide range of '''secular Christmas stories''', told in popular music, on television, and in the cinema, that are told about the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[holiday]] of Christmas, that may be based on or allegorize the biblical [[Christian mythology]] of Christmas, as the birth of Jesus, but not necessarily. The stories may also have newer interpretations and introduce new characters (such as [[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer|Rudolph the reindeer]]). These secular Christmas stories could be classified as [[mythopoeia]] (invented mythology), or Christian [[allegory|allegories]].
==In popular music, on television, and in the cinema== [[Santa Claus]] is the English name for the Christian [[Saint Nicholas]], secularized in popular culture as an old man with supernatural powers living at the [[North Pole]], much like magic and powerful characters in mythology: Santa Claus has supernatural powers and uses them to magnanimously deliver gifts to children around the world. Santa was based on the legends of [[Saint Nicholas]]. Santa was given an amplified mythological identity in the [[Clement Moore]] poem ''[[A Visit from St. Nicholas]]'' (the title of which is often misidentified as ''Twas The Night Before Christmas.'') Comparative mythologies have also noted the ancient Germanic myths of [[Thor]] driving a cart led by goats in the sky (which led to the folklore of the [[Yule Goat]]) is like Santa driving a sleigh led by reindeers in the sky, so think Santa may stem from both Christian and pre-Christian Germanic mythology.
In the 1950s, several Christmas cartoons emerged that deliberately adopt elements of Christian stories to convey the "true meaning of Christmas" in allegorical terms.
An early film, ''[[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (TV special)]]'' based on a [[Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer|Gene Autry song]], involved a rejected and mocked reindeer that ends up leading the other reindeer through the help of a misfit elf and misfit toys.
Similarly, ''[[Frosty the Snowman]]'' contains several Christian motifs, is the story of a snowman who comes to life for a time, melts (dies) but also reassures his childlike followers that he will "be back again some day." The television special developed from this song invents the concept of Frosty being made from "Christmas snow" which entails that he can never completely melt away and thus has an eternal essence.
Following these early television Christmas specials, there have been countless other Christmas TV specials and movies produced for the "holiday season" that are not explicitly Christian but seek to describe "true spirit of Christmas" beliefs, such as "togetherness," "being with family," charitable acts, and belief that even bad people or situations can be redeemed. While many sundry examples of [[:Category:Christmas films|Christmas films]] exist, examples of films with Christian mythical elements include: ''[[How the Grinch Stole Christmas! (film)]],'' ''[[A Charlie Brown Christmas]],'' and various adaptations of ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'' by [[Charles Dickens]].
These conceptions of the "true meaning of Christmas" are also sung about in Christmas albums.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Dictionary}}{{unreferenced|date=May 2012}} '''Skanger''' is a derogatory term for a person, mainly in [[Ireland]], roughly equivalent to the British [[chav]]. Both words refer to a socioeconomic grouping typical of low income urban [[working class]] youths. There are many stereotypes of each group, and [[popular culture]] often openly ridicule many aspects of the lifestyle. Typically skangers are associated with aggressive attitudes, lack of respect for police force, anti social behaviour, street drinking and drug abuse.
==See also== *[[Spide]] *[[Boy racer]]
==External links== *[[wikt:skanger|Skanger]] on [[Wiktionary]]

'''Social services''' are a range of [[public service]]s provided by the government, private, profit and non-profit organizations. These public services aim to create more effective organizations, build stronger communities, and promote equality and opportunity.Social services bring a type of nationalism in ourselves.Social services bring a lot of change in our society.
Social services include the benefits and facilities such as education, food subsidies, health care, police, fire service, job training and subsidized housing, adoption, community management, policy research, and lobbying.<ref>{{cite web|title=Making a Difference: Community Practice for Social Change|url=http://socialworkdegree.case.edu/resources/infographic/making-a-difference/|website=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30%}} *[[Australian referendum, 1946 (Social Services)]] *[[Department of Social Services]] *[[Department for Communities and Local Government|Department for Communities and Local Government (UK)]] *[[Emergency Social Services]] *[[Human services]] *[[International Social Services]] *[[Ministry of Community and Social Services (Ontario)]] *[[New York State Social Services Department]] *[[Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government|Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government (UK)]] *[[Social Welfare (constituency)]] {{div col end}}
==References== <References/>

:''Not to be confused with the [[political activist]] group [[Students for a Democratic Society]] (SDS).'' {{Disability}} The '''Society for Disability Studies''' is an international academic network of [[disability studies]] practitioners.{{cite web|url=http://www.disstudies.org/about |title=About SDS - Society for Disability Studies|publisher=disstudies.org|accessdate=2010-11-21}} It often abbreviates its name to '''SDS''', though that abbreviation continues to be used by academics and [[political scientists]] to describe the [[Students for a Democratic Society]] organization in the [[United States]]. The society's overall goal is to promote disability studies as a serious [[academic discipline]] on par with [[philosophy]], the [[social sciences]], and similar fields.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/03/education/edlife/disability-studies-a-new-normal.html |first=Cecilia Capuzzi |last=Simon |title=Disability Studies: A New Normal |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=2013-11-03 |accessdate=2015-10-20}} ==Definition of disability studies== In 1993 the society adopted an official definition of "Disability Studies":
"... examines the policies and practices of all societies to understand the social, rather than the physical or psychological determinants of the experience of disability. Disability Studies has been developed to disentangle impairments from the myths, ideology and stigma that influence social interaction and social policy. The scholarship challenges the idea that the economic and social statuses and the assigned roles of people with disabilities are the inevitable outcomes of their condition."{{cite web|url=http://www.crds.org/about/index.shtml|title=Community Rehabilitation and Disability Studies - University of Calgary|publisher=crds.org|accessdate=2010-11-21}}
== Founding and history == The organization was founded in 1982 first as the '''Section for the Study of Chronic Illness, Impairment, and Disability''' (SSCIID), and renamed '''Society for Disability Studies''' in 1986.{{Cite web|title = Mission & History {{!}} Society for Disability Studies|url = http://www.disstudies.org/about/mission-and-history|website = www.disstudies.org|access-date = 2016-02-18}} Its founders are Daryl Evans, Nora Groce, Steve Hey, Gary Kiger, John Seidel, Jessica Scheer and Irving Kenneth Zola (1935-1994).{{Cite web|title = Mission & History {{!}} Society for Disability Studies|url = http://www.disstudies.org/about/mission-and-history|website = www.disstudies.org|access-date = 2016-02-18}} The Society for Disability Studies is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization. The Society maintains affiliation status with the Western Social Science Associationhttp://www.wssaweb.com (WSSA) through its Chronic Disease and Disability section. Currently, the SDS has hundreds of members both nationally and internationally who continue to make disability studies a part of academic conversations. ==Activities and publications== The Society for Disability Studies holds an annual conference{{cite web|url=http://www.disstudies.org/annual-conference |title=Annual Conference - Society for Disability Studies|publisher=disstudies.org |date=2008-06-21|accessdate= 2010-11-21}} in June and publishes a quarterly peer-reviewed journal, the ''Disability Studies Quarterly''.http://dsq-sds.org{{cite web|url=http://www.dsq-sds.org/ |title=Disability Studies Quarterly|publisher=dsq-sds.org|accessdate=2010-11-21}} The journal is published exclusively online.{{cite web|url=http://dsq-sds.org|title=Disability Studies Quarterly - Society for Disability Studies|publisher=disstudies.org|accessdate= 2010-11-21}} SDS has created a good model to follow when approaching publishers about their accessibility.{{Cite web|url = http://www.disstudies.org/Publishing%20Accessible%20Books|title = Publishing Accessible Books|date = |access-date = 2016-02-16|website = Society for Disabilities|publisher = |last = |first = }} In 2015, Adam Newman organized the "Digital Access Facilitation Team" (DAFT)http://www.crowdrise.com/DigitalAccessFacilitationTeam-SDS2015/fundraiser/adamnewman1/1/return/success/success to make the 2015 annual conference of the Society for Disability Studies more accessible for a wider range of attendees. DAFT is coordinated by the Society's Student Caucus, whose members are a group of 25-30 students of SDS. Working in teams of two, members of DAFT were live-tweeting every session, contingent upon the consent of presenters. Live-tweeting all sessions and following standards for that emerging media, allowed a new way of producing accessibility for the disability community.{{Cite web|title = Digital Access Facilitation Team - SDS 2015 {{!}} Adam Newman's Fundraiser|url = http://www.crowdrise.com/DigitalAccessFacilitationTeam-SDS2015/fundraiser/adamnewman1/1/return/success/success|website = Crowdrise|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = en-US}} In the Society for Disability Studies, there are a number of caucuses which “designate groups that are under-represented within society or SDS as an organization.” DAFT is composed entirely of students (undergraduate, graduate, professional) who work on behalf of the interest and needs of students.{{Cite web|title = SDS Student Caucus|url = http://sdsstudentcaucus.wordpress.com|website = SDS Student Caucus|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = en-US}} == Membership == There are several options for membership opportunities, even if someone is unable to pay the membership fees they will not be turned away; "No one is denied membership in SDS due to an inability to pay an established membership fee."{{Cite web|title = join SDS {{!}} Society for Disability Studies|url = http://www.disstudies.org/membership/join|website = www.disstudies.org|access-date = 2016-02-16}} == Awards == Two awards have been established by the society "to honor individuals who have shown dedication to Disability studies": the ''Senior Scholar Award'' and the ''Irving K. Zola Award for Emerging Scholars in Disability Studies''.{{cite web|url=http://www.disstudies.org/awards|title=SDS Awards - Society for Disability Studies|publisher=disstudies.org|accessdate=2010-11-21}} The ''Senior Scholar Award'' is awarded to individuals who have made significant contributions to the field of disability studies. Past award winners: Devva Kasnitz (2014), Richard Scotch (2013), Carol Gill (2012), Tobin Siebers (2011), Rosemarie Garland Thomson (2010), Elizabeth Depoy and Stephen Gilson (2009), and Steven J. Taylor (2008).{{cite web|url=http://www.disstudies.org/awards/sds-senior-scholar|title=SDS Senior Scholar - Society for Disability Studies|publisher=disstudies.org|accessdate=2010-11-21}} On the contrary, the ''Irving K. Zola Award for Emerging Scholars in Disability Studies'' is awarded to an up and coming individual who also has made significant contributions to the field of disability studies. == Current Board of Directors 2017-2018 == * President and Chairperson - Phil Smith{{Cite web|title = 2015-2016 Board of Directors {{!}} Society for Disability Studies|url = http://www.disstudies.org/about/executive-board|website = www.disstudies.org|access-date = 2016-02-18}} * Vice-Chairperson - Joanne Woiak * Treasurer - Carol Goldin * Secretary - Katherine Caldwell == List of SDS Presidents == Below is a list of the current and past presidents of the SDS.{{Cite web|title = Founders & Past Presidents {{!}} Society for Disability Studies|url = http://www.disstudies.org/about/past-presidents|website = www.disstudies.org|access-date = 2016-02-23}} {| class="wikitable" !Years Active !Name |- |1986-89 |Irving K. Zola (founder) |- |1989-90 |Daryl Evans (founder) |- |1990-91 |Barbara Altman |- |1991-93 |David Pfeiffer |- |1993-94 |Sharon Barnartt |- |1994-95 |Richard Scotch |- |1995-96 |Corinne Kirchner |- |1996-98 |Adrienne Asch |- |1998-00 |David Mitchell |- |2000-02 |Phil Ferguson |- |2002-05 |Anne Finger |- |2005-06 |Jim Ferris |- |2006 |Corbett O'Toole |- |2006-07 |Chris Bell |- |2006-08 |Elaine Gerber |- |2008-09 |Noam Ostrander |- |2009-10 |Pamela Block |- |2010-12 |Devva Kasnitz |- |2012-14 |Tammy Berberi |- |2014-15 |Michael Rembis |- |2015-2016 |Brenda Brueggemann |- |2016-Present |Phil Smith |} == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Monaghan, P. "Pioneering Field of Disability Studies Challenges Established Approaches and Attitudes." ''Chronicle of Higher Education'', (January 23, 1998). * Ramirez, A. "Disability as Field of Study?" ''New York Times'', 21 December 1997. == External links == * {{official|http://www.disstudies.org }} * [http://www.dsq-sds.org/ ''Disability Studies Quarterly'' Journal website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Society For Disability Studies}} [[Category:Disability organizations]] [[Category:Disability studies]] [[Category:International learned societies]] [[Category:Social sciences organizations]] [[Category:International organizations based in the United States]]

{{Infobox Korean name |img=Sotdae.JPG |caption=''Sotdae'' |hangul=솟대 |hanja=none |rr=sotdae |mr=sottae }}
A '''''sotdae''''' ({{IPA-ko|sot.t͈ɛ}}) is a tall wooden [[Column|pole]] or stone pillar with a carved bird on its top, built for the purpose of folk belief in [[Korea]].<ref name="WPost">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/07/AR2007060701080.html?tid=informbox |title=Smithsonian to Open Korea Gallery |publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=2008-07-14 |author=Randolph E. Schmid |date=2007-07-07}}</ref><ref name="inabi">{{cite web|url=http://www.inabi.or.kr/hampyeong/english/travel_info/s_05.html |title=Totem Pole Park (Sotdae and Jangseung Park) |publisher=The official stie of Hampyeong County |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref><ref name="JoongAng Dalily">{{cite news|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1908245 |title=(HEUNGBO'S GOURD)Sotdae - a symbol worth saving |publisher=[[JoongAng Daily]] |author=Gary Rector |date=2002-09-06 |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref> Like ''[[jangseung]]'', wooden [[totem pole]]s with a sculptured human face, it was usually erected near the entrance of a village to ward off evil spirits as well as to represent villagers' wishes for prosperity and well-being.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" /><ref name="EncyKorea">{{cite web|url=http://100.empas.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=K&i=253403&v=46 |title=Sotdae 솟대|publisher=[[Empas]] / [[EncyKorea]] |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref> Later, it was also built as a celebratory or commemorative symbol. For instance, when a son of a family passed a civil service examination called ''[[gwageo]]'', a ''sotdae'' was set up in the yard.<ref name="EncyKorea" /> In that case, it was colored in orange and topped with a blue dragon.<ref name="Doosan">{{cite web|url=http://www.encyber.com/search_w/ctdetail.php?masterno=95266&contentno=95266 |title=Sotdae 솟대|publisher=[[Doosan Encyclopedia]] |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref>
==Features== ''Sotdae'' were generally set up alone, but sometimes, along with ''[[jangseung]]'' (Korean totem poles), ''dolta''p (돌탑, a [[pagoda]] built with stone) or ''sinmok'' (신목, sacred trees). It was worshiped as a village guardian. The birds may look like wild geese, [[crow]]s or ibises in some areas, but [[duck]]s are the most common.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" /><ref name="kois" /> ''Sotdae'' have different names according to regions; ''soju'' (소주), ''sojutdae'' (소줏대) in [[Jeolla Province]], ''soldae'' (솔대) in [[Gangwon (historical)|Gangwon Province]] and [[Hamhung]] district,<ref name="Doosan" /> ''byeolsindae'' (별신대) in coastal areas of [[Gyeongsang Province]],and ''sotdaek'' (솟댁) in [[Hwanghae]] and [[Pyeongan Province]]. ''Pyojutdae'' (표줏대), ''georitdae'' (거릿대), ''susalmok'' (수살목) and ''seonangdae'' (선앙대) are other names.<ref name="inabi" />
Nothing precise is known about the sotdae's origin. However, ''sotdae'' was believed to be sanctified as a village guardian from when people started agriculture and the unit of society formed based on agricultural villages.<ref name="EncyKorea" /> Later, as a concept of [[feng shui]] prevailed and values of success and honour became important, its meaning seemed to be differentiated from an object of worship to a totem for abundant harvest.<ref name="Britannica" /> Ducks, as migratory birds, had various religious symbols and made the meanings of ''sotdae'' more diverse.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" />
==Origins of worshipping ''sotdae''== The worship of ''sotdae''-like objects was commonly found in [[North Asia]].<ref name="Britannica">{{cite web|url=http://100.empas.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=B&i=158384&v=44 |title=Sotdae (솟대) |publisher=[[Empas]] / [[Britannica]] |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref> Figures or patterns on [[Bronze Age]] relics that included a pole with a bird on it were discovered around these areas. As people began to develop techniques for metalworking and increased their agriculture production, power differences among tribes emerged. Dominating class sought a political and religious foundation needed to maintain their powers from gods in the heaven.<ref name=autogenerated1>Lee, Pil-yeong, ''Sotdae''</ref><ref name="heritagebusan">{{cite web|url=http://www.heritagebusan.com/droom/di-11.htm |title=Part 11. Sotdae: Duck, could you send a message to the heaven regarding our dream? (11편 솟대 : 오리야, 우리 꿈을 하늘에 전해주렴)|publisher=Busan Cultural Tourism Guiders Association (부산문화관광해설사회) |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref> So it was assumed that appearance of sotdae stemmed from the integration between ''"[[Cosmic Tree]]"'' and ''"Sky-Birds"''.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name="heritagebusan" />
A similar sacred pole is found among the [[Omaha (tribe)|Omaha tribe]] of the central United States.
==Components of sotdae and their meanings==
===Poles and posts=== Poles and posts have religious and symbolic meanings around the world. Poles of sotdae are related to 'the world-axis'. There are three cosmic levels in the concept of the universe in Northern Asian [[shamanism]] ― upper, middle, and lower level. They are connected to each other by the world-axis.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> A tree has roots extending into the earth and also grows toward the sky, which could be a symbol for the world-axis. So the wooden poles or posts were possibly considered to be a pathway for spiritual beings to come down to earth and they became a sacred object to worship by themselves.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> A similar record was found in a book titled ''Dongguksesigi'' (동국세시기, 東國歲時記), which said that 12 wooden poles were set up to welcome a god on February 2 in [[Jeju island]].<ref name="Jeju">{{cite web|url=http://www.jejutimes.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=27509 |title=The legends, myths, folklores related Jeju horse 3(제주마와 관련된 신화ㆍ전설 및 민속 등 Ⅲ) |publisher=Jeju Times |author=Prof. Jang Deok-ji (장덕지 교수) |language=Korean |date=2006-08-09 |accessdate=2008-07-14 |quote= 동국여지승람(東國與地勝覽)과 동국세시기(東國歲時記)에는 제주목(濟州牧)편에 이에 관한 기록이 있다. 2월 초하룻날 귀덕, 김녕 등지에서는 나뭇대 12개를 세워 신을 맞이하여 제사를 지낸다.}}</ref> Also ''[[Dangun]]'' 's father, ''Hwanung'', descended from the heaven to the top of a tree, ''Sindansu'' (신단수, 神壇樹) in Korea's founding myth.<ref>[http://uriul.or.kr/zeroboard/zboard.php?id=10_6&page=33&sn1=&divpage=1&sn=off&ss=on&sc=on&select_arrange=headnum&desc=asc&no=91 ÀïÁ¡¹È<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> People selected a tree which was beyond the reach of humans and they conducted ceremonial rites before they cut down the tree. On top of that, the poles and posts were believed to offer protection a village against calamities and disasters and also acted like a mast in a U-shaped land area balancing and making the land stable.<ref>[http://www.heritagebusan.com/droom/di-11.htm ¼Ú´ë<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Birds=== Sotdae birds may be wild geese, gulls, ibises, Korean magpies or crows, but most commonly they are ducks.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" /> Ducks give an important symbolic meaning to sotdae. They are able to travel on water as well as on land and in the air and also can go under water. Because of the relation to water, ducks were regarded to have an ability to control rain and thunder, to survive in the floods and to protect a village from fire. This belief made people think of ducks as a guardian in ancient agricultural societies.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" /><ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name="heritagebusan" /> Relating to this, a famous scholar, Lee Gyubo (이규보, 李奎報 1168–1241) wrote a following phrase in his garland called ''Dongguk I sangguk jip'' (동국이상국집, 東國李相國集: Collected works of Minister Yi of Korea): "Because of the rain for 7 days in a row, the capital of Songyang was submerged. The king, Jumong, was riding a duck horse stretching a reed rope across the river and his people were all holding that rope." This suggests that people considered a duck as a rescuer from flood.<ref name="kois">{{cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/kois/magazine/pictorialKoreaView.asp?Html_no=252 |title=Sotdae: Embodying Wishes for Prosperity |publisher=Korean Overseas Information Service |accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref>
Another characteristic of ducks is that they are migratory birds coming to Korea in autumn. Migratory birds appear and disappear on a regular basis and it was believed that ducks travel to the world beyond the Earth and act as a messenger between the physical world and the realm of the spirits. In agriculture, this periodicity might be associated with the cycle of monsoon which brings rain. Also, the fact that ducks are fertile species and lay bigger eggs than chickens do would be a good reason for ducks to be an idolized object representing abundance.<ref name="JoongAng Dalily" />
====''Meaning of the number of birds and their direction''==== The shape of birds on sotdae was carved as minutely as possible but it was sometimes simplified to just Y or ㄱ shape. The number of birds seated on sotdae was different from village to village, from one to three. Commonly one bird was seated on a pole, but sometimes two or three birds on a Y-shape branch were found on a pole ― either facing each other or facing the same direction. Nothing is exactly known concerning the number of birds but it is assumed that the number of birds on a pole was decided according to the number of places which '[[qi]]' should be complemented.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> The direction of the bird's heads varies. People made sotdae erected toward south to wish moderate weather for farming or let it direct north to bring rain. Sometimes sotdae turned toward the outside of the village to make sure that ducks take all the evil spirits and fly away.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name="heritagebusan" />
==See also== *[[Jangseung]] *[[Dol hareubang]] *[[Totem pole]] *[[Korean shamanism]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} *{{cite book|author=Lee, Pil-yeong (이필영)|year=1990 |title=Sotdae (솟대)|publisher=Daewonsa |isbn=89-369-0015-3 |language=Korean }} *{{cite book|author=The National Academy of the Korean Language |year=2002 |title=Illustrated Guide to Korean Culture; 233 traditional keywords |publisher=Hakgojae|isbn=89-85846-98-1 }} *{{cite book|author=National Institute of Korean History |year=2002 |title=Korean History |publisher=Ministry of Education & Human Resources Development |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-07-14}} *{{cite web|url=http://eng.korean.net/wcms/list.jsp?pageID=04025274&bID=4391&byid=1 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20081222194119/http://eng.korean.net/wcms/list.jsp?pageID=04025274&bID=4391&byid=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-12-22 |title=Cultural Symbols |publisher=The Overseas Koreans Foundation |accessdate=2008-07-14}}
==External links== *[http://image.search.naver.com/search.naver?where=image&sm=tab_jum&query=%uC19F%uB300 Images of sotdae]
[[Category:Korean culture]]

revision.text:
{{About|the art form|the record label|spinART Records}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2007}}
[[Image:spinartjg.jpg|thumb|right|''Spin art'']] '''Spin art''' is an art form that uses [[paint]], a canvas such as glossy cardboard and a spinning platform. It is primarily used to entertain and expose [[children]] to the process of art creation, although it can be enjoyed by people of all ages.
==Techniques== [[Image:SPINARTTIMELAPSE.gif|thumb|left|''Spin art time lapse'']] To create spin art, an artist initially decorates or drips paint onto a canvas. The canvas can be anything; however, the most common form of canvas is a small rectangular piece of cardboard. Before the paint on the canvas dries, the artist secures the canvas to a platform that can be rotated at high speed. Once the canvas is secure, the artist can then begin spinning the canvas. Most spinning platforms are electrical or battery operated, with more elaborate platforms enabling the artist to vary the rotational speed.
As the canvas rotates, [[centrifugal force]]s draw the wet paint outwards, creating intricate designs. The artist can drip more paint onto the canvas while it is spinning, thus layering paints on top of each other, creating different effects. Using different colors, a skilled spin artist can blend colors together into subtle designs. At any point during this process, the artist can stop the spinning platform to view the canvas. Since the canvas is usually rotating at a high rate, it is difficult if not impossible to view the image on the canvas until the platform has stopped spinning, thus creating a sense of surprise and uncertainty during the creation process.
<gallery> File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 01.jpg|Making spin art on old phonograph records. Paint is applied… File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 02.jpg|…and the disc is spun at a rapid rate… File:Artopia 2009 - spin art 03.jpg|…resulting in a spin art piece. </gallery>
==Fine art== <!-- done, perhaps {{Cleanup section|reason=full of artists with no valid references|date=January 2014}} --> [[Image:Spin painting annick gendron.jpg|thumb|right| ''Spin painting",oil on [[plexiglas]] by Annick Gendron (1969)]]
Since the 1960s spin art can be seen in the works of certain contemporary artists. The artists using this technique often reconfigure their own machines by incorporating a more powerful engine than those belonging to schools. The variety of results that this technique produces gives us a good idea of the infinite possibilities. [[Image:Hirst-Beautiful.jpg|thumb|right| ''Beautiful revolving sphincter, oops brown painting'' by Damien Hirst (2003)]]
Professional artists:
'''Alfons Schilling''' {{main article|Alfons Schilling}} During the 1960s Alfons Schilling was one of the first artists to become interested in spin art. action painting also had a large influence on his work and added to its originality. Instead of installing it vertically he did it horizontally.
'''Annick Gendron''' {{main article|Annick Gendron}} From 1968 to 1973 the French artist Annick Gendron used industrial wheels to spin paint on Plexiglas. At the end of the 1960s she was one of the first artist to use centrifugal force to produce large-sized artworks. Inspired by children's games : spin art, spin painting, her goal was to transcend this modest use to get the most spectacular effects from it. Damien Hirst got the same idea in the 1990s, as her he transcends the original practice, by the use of more spectacular materials, sizes, shapes, and skill improvement. Her work has been shown at the Raymond Duncan Gallery, at the [[Bernheim-Jeune]] Gallery, at the Salon des Indépendants and Surindependant at the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, at the Salon des Artistes Français at the Grand Palais and the Salon d'Automne in Paris.
'''Damien Hirst''' {{main article|Damien Hirst}} From 1995 the British artist Damien Hirst started a series of spin paintings. His finished pieces are circular in shape and mounted onto steel frames. This is a series of original works of art and screen prints. He was inspired by memories of the technique of spin painting which he saw as a child on the BBC's ''Blue Peter''.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/hirsts-spinning-wheel-brings-good-fortune-1155421.html Hirst's spinning wheel brings good fortune]</ref>
'''Lawrence Stafford'''
During the late 1960s developed a spinning rotating machine on which he attached raw canvas and sprayed acrylic paint while the drum spun. He exhibited those abstract paintings in the United States and in Germany in 1968-1969. Several are in important museum collections including the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].<ref>[http://www.abstract-art.com/abstraction/l1_7pntgrs_Show_fldr/47Stafford.html Abstract-Art.com, Lawrence Stafford]</ref>
'''Mark Chadwick'''
Mark Chadwick's art is concerned by the use of machines in a production of an artwork, questioning what happens to an artwork once a machine has been used in its production. Chadwick often creates paintings using the spinning technique to introduce the element of chance and questioning the control of the artist. He consistently changes the method and considers all types of aspects to create different works.<ref>http://www.riseart.com/article/2013-05-01-introducing-mark-chadwick</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.alfons-schilling.com/ Alfons Schilling official] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090129111117/http://asso-action-art.fr/actionart/annick%20gendron.html Annick Gendron biography] * [http://www.whitecube.com/artists/hirst// White cube : Damien Hirst]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spin Art}} [[Category:Art genres]]

{{Infobox church | name = The Church of Saint Martin | fullname = The Church of Saint Martin within the Golden Gate | color = | image = File:20130603 Split 085.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = The Church of Saint Martin | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | architect = | style = [[Ancient Roman architecture|Ancient]]/[[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] | years built = 4th century | bishop = [[Marin Barišić]]<ref>[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dspli.html Archdiocese of Split-Makarska]</ref> | country = {{flag|Croatia}} }} '''St. Martin's Church''' ({{lang-hr|Crkva Svetog Martina}}), is a Roman Catholic church in [[Split, Croatia|Split]], [[Croatia]]. Built into a small space (an early guardhouse) within the ancient [[Golden Gate (Diocletian's Palace)|Golden Gate]] of Diocletian's northern wall above the Golden Gate ([[Porta aurea]]).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.inyourpocket.com/split/The-Church-of-Saint-Martin-Golden-gate_34729v|title=The Church of Saint Martin (Golden gate) {{!}} Sightseeing {{!}} Split|website=www.inyourpocket.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitsplit.com/en/1240/church-of-st-martin|title=Split - Church of St. Martin|website=www.visitsplit.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref> Today St. Martin's Church is one of Split's tourist attractions (one of only two closest churches in the city) and while it is in the care of the Dominican sisters, who have a monastery next door, it is open to the public to visit.
==History== located in a cavity of the west wall above the Golden Gate of [[Diocletian's Palace]]. That space, in the time of [[Diocletian]] (285-305), was a narrow corridor (10 x 1.65 m)<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> that was used as a guardhouse, with the windows on the south side for surveillance. These remain well preserved to the present day in their original form, while windows on the north side date from the city's defence against the Ottoman Turks. The inscription along the architrave of the entrance door:
<poem> REX BENEDICTE D(EU)S, LAUDIS DECUS IMPERI V(IRTUS)Q(UE. (H)ANC (ECCLESIAM) CONSTITUIT SUB (H)ONORE(M) BEATI MARTINI (H)UMIL(I)TE(R) (HA)EC ATQ(UE) POTE(N)S P(RES)B(Y)T(E)R DOMINICUS. SALVE PA(TER)...T TIBI P(ER) N(OST)RI PECTORIS ANTRA COLI. </poem>
translated by archaeologist [[Frane Bulić]] reads: (Blessed by God, our King, to you the glory, honour and power! Founding this Church for the glory of the blessed Martin, in modesty and according to your means the priest Dominic. "Hail Father Martin, allow us to worship you from the bottom of our soul and heart in this small cavern") In identifying Dominic, Bulić dated the inscription to the ninth century and the region of [[Trpimir I of Croatia|Trpimir I]]. It seems the ([[Knez (title)|knez]]) chaplain Dominic, renovated the former guardhouse into the first Christian church in the city dedicated to the [[Virgin Mary]], [[Pope Saint Gregory I|Saint Gregory I]] and [[Martin of Tours|St. Martin of Tours]] (the father of western monasticism).
On 4 March 852 Trpimir issued a charter in [[Biaći]] (''in loco Byaci dicitur'') in the [[Latin]] language, confirming [[Mislav of Croatia|Mislav]]'s donations to the [[Archbishopric]] in [[Split (city)|Split]]. The charter is preserved in a copy from 1568. In this document, Trpimir named himself "by the mercy of God, Duke of the Croats" ({{lang-la|Dux Chroatorum iuvatus munere divino}}) and his realm as the "Realm of the Croats" (''Regnum Chroatorum'').<ref name=Curta>[[Florin Curta]]: [https://books.google.com/books?id=YIAYMNOOe0YC Southeastern Europe in the Middle Ages], 500-1250, p. 139</ref><ref>Codex Diplomaticus Regni Croatiæ, Dalamatiæ et Slavoniæ, Vol I, p. 4-8</ref> The term ''regnum'' was used by other rulers of that time as a sign of their independence and did not necessarily mean a [[Monarchy|kingdom]].<ref>Rudolf Horvat: Povijest Hrvatske I. (od najstarijeg doba do g. 1657.), 17. Mislav i Trpimir</ref> The charter documents Trpimir's decision to build a [[Church (building)|church]] (possibly St Martin's) and the first [[Benedictine monastery]] in [[Rižinice]], thus bringing the [[Benedictine|Benedictins]] into Croatia.<ref name=Curta/><ref name=general>{{cite web|url=http://krk.fcpages.com/hr/vladari/trp.html|title=Hrvatska povijest: Hrvatski knez Trpimir|work=fcpages.com}}</ref>
On the architrave, together with his own name, Trpimir also had the name of his other chaplain (also called Martin). The Main altar too dates from the 9th century.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.split.hr/citylights/6/index_en.html|title=Split.hr {{!}} The Golden Gate|website=www.split.hr|language=hr-HR|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> The church later provided certain amenities such as a settlement for Dominican sisters (which dates as far back as the 14th century).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gpsmycity.com/attractions/church-of-saint-martin-9831.html|title=Church of Saint Martin in Split, Croatia|website=www.gpsmycity.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref> It was rediscovered in 1890 by Bulić, following his study of the palace and recommended its renovation. on that occasion, the new altar and nave were built. In 1929, during the enlargement of one of the windows, a tablet was discovered with an engraved inscription: "The unworthy servant, priest Dominic, chaplain of Duke Trpimir". Bulić believed that this might represent the gravestone of Dominic. Today it is kept [[Archaeological Museum Split|Archaeological Museum]].
==Architecture== The northern gate of the Palace had been conceived as the main entrance and so it had been elaborately decorated with statues of Emperor [[Diocletian]] and his co-regent [[Maximian]], in the upper row of the niches, the nd with sculpture of an eagle (a symbol of [[Jupiter (god)|Jupiter]]), between the two. There were the statues of their two successors to the throne - [[Caesar (title)|Caesar's]] [[Galerius]] and [[Constantine]] - in the lower row of the niches. This conclusion can be made on account of the imperial iconography pattern, effective at the time of tetrarchy (rule by four persons). On the top of the wall, there have been four pedestals preserved until the present day (while there were five of them on the drawings from the 18th century), that could have been used as a supporting base for statues, but it is unlikely to believe that the imperial figures would have been repeated twice on the same façade. So far there has not been a veritable explanation given for this double usage.<ref name=":2" /> This could be concluded by the presence of patron saints, (later added) to whom the other gates of the Imperial Palace had been dedicated: [[Theodore, Philippa and companions|St. Theodore]] (The Western Gate), [[Apollinaris of Ravenna|St Apollinaris]] (The Eastern Gate) and [[Julian of Antioch|St. Julian]] (The Southern Gate). [[St. Martin]] (patron saint of soldiers), like St. Theodore was worshipped in the later Roman period, particularly in the West, during the rule of the Emperor [[Justinian]] (527-565).
Church central area divided into two parts altar screen, made of marble and covered in vines, grape vines and griffon;<ref>http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Split/tabid/72/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/78308/Default.aspx</ref> on the space with an altar that was intended for the clergy and boat that was intended for laymen. On the altar wall of the altar, the only preserved in situ in Dalmatia, there is an inscription with the dedication of the Virgin Mary, St. Gregory the Pope and Blessed Martin:<ref>Marasović, Tomislav, Split in the Old Croatian Age, p16</ref>
"''This church is under the patronage of Blessed Martha, the Virgin Mary and the Holy Gregorian Pope.''"
The pre-Romanesque stage, probably built in the 9th century, belongs to the barrel vault, an altar in the apse with a carved cross of early Christian denominations and a small trance, set in the middle of large, buried antique openings on the southern wall. The later pre-Romanesque stage of the 11th century belongs to the altarpiece and the bell tower, which was later destroyed.<ref>Marasović, Tomislav, Split u starohrvatsko doba, str. 16.-17.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Cathedral of Split}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090221103959/http://www.split.hr/ Grad Split] Official Split web page {{hr icon}} * [http://www.nadbiskupija-split.com/ Splitsko-makarska nadbiskupija] Official Archdiocese web page {{hr icon}} * [http://www.split.hr/citylights/6/index_en.html] {{hr icon}}
